content:
I'm at a loss about how to fix this build error: https://github.com/teorth/equational_theories/pull/115/checks

Anyone have ideas? I suspect installing blueprint locally is going to be necessary going forward.
The error says "Undefined control sequence.\G "
Could be an accidentally introduced space in \Gamma or could be a missing $ sign for math mode.
see this line: https://github.com/teorth/equational_theories/pull/115/checks#step:10:450
The problem is in \G\models\Gamma on line 65
Wow ok, thanks a bunch, I think I'm just tired
Has the issue been resolved, or is further assistance required?

That one has, but I'm still at a loss of how blueprint works; how does one refer to a given lean definition? (basically I'm trying to fix these failures: https://github.com/teorth/equational_theories/actions/runs/11098739045/job/30831898895?pr=123)
I’ll take a look at your issue when I get back home tonight.

But that seems easy enough to solve it via mobile. You just need to include the namespace of the lean declaration in the \lean{} macro.

If that doesn’t help, don’t worry. I’ll help you later.
Ok, I see you fixed it.
I fixed it by deleting all the \lean{} invocations so your help is appreciated :)

Let's start with \lean{MagmaLaw}.

Your LaTeX environment 

\begin{definition}[Law]\label{law-def}
  \lean{MagmaLaw}
  \uses{induced-def}
  Let $X$ be a set. A \emph{law} with alphabet $X$ is a formal expression of the form $w \formaleq w'$,
  where $w, w' \in M_X$ are words with alphabet $X$ (thus one can identify laws with alphabet $X$ with
  elements of $M_X \times M_X$). A magma $G$ \emph{satisfies} the law $w \formaleq w'$ if we have
  $\varphi_f( w ) = \varphi_f ( w' )$ for all $f: X \to G$, in which case we write $G \models w \formaleq w'$.
\end{definition}

is perfectly fine, but if you locally run: 

lake exe checkdecls blueprint/lean_decls

it throws the following error: 

MagmaLaw is missing.

Is this your problem, right?
Correct

Now that I am in your PR-related branch, I can see that 

structure MagmaLaw (α : Type) where
  lhs : FreeMagma α
  rhs : FreeMagma α
deriving DecidableEq

is declared in the Completeness.lean file.

There two different types of problems here:

  1. The Completeness.lean is not error-free: the proof of the theorem substLFIdreturns an error;
  2. There is no import equational_theories.Completeness in the build file equational_theories.lean.

This is why you get the MagmaLaw is missing error: equational_theories.Completeness is not run when you build the project and the blueprint can only see the LaTeX declaration (\lean{Magmalaw} in the LaTeX definition environment which is saved in the blueprint/lean_decls file), but not the corresponding Lean declaration.
Notice that at the moment you cannot even run the Compactness.lean file since it depends on the Completeness.lean file.
Hope it helps.

This is a golden rule of Lean projects that has nothing to do with blueprints. You should never ever push code that contains errors. Sorries are fine, errors will make your collaborators hate you and there will be divine punishment even without collaborators :wink:

I have also reviewed the relevant commit and noticed the following LaTeX definition environment / declaration: 

\begin{definition}[Law]
    \label{law-def}
    \uses{induced-def}
    \lean{MagmaLaw}
    Let $X$ be a set. A \emph{law} with alphabet $X$ is a formal expression of the form $w \formaleq w'$,
    where $w, w' \in M_X$ are words with alphabet $X$ (thus one can identify laws with alphabet $X$ with
    elements of $M_X \times M_X$).  A magma $G$ \emph{satisfies}\lean{satisfies} the law $w \formaleq w'$
    if we have $\varphi_f( w ) = \varphi_f ( w' )$ for all $f: X \to G$, in which case we write $G \models w \formaleq w'$.
\end{definition}

That \lean{satisfies} should not be there: if you want to subsume multiple Lean declarations under a single LaTeX declaration you need to provide the list of Lean declarations as an argument to the \lean{} macro.

But that satifies is probably supposed to be an argument of the \uses{} macro, right?
Oh yes, this will definitely not work. A given declaration should have only one \lean, potentially with several arguments.
I agree, of course; what's confusing me is that these checks are all green: https://github.com/teorth/equational_theories/actions/runs/11111270277/job/30870809069?pr=123
Ah I see, I'll fix this all when I get home from the Proof Mines.
I admit that git shenanigans and rebasing have been considerably more challenging than the proofs themselves

A couple of suggestions to get ahead of git:

  1. Don't rebase. Always merge.
  2. Use the git graph vscode extension
I think rebase killed me here, lesson learned (though @Soonho Kong tried in vain to teach me)
You can run git config pull.rebase false
By doing this you guarantee a merge
That is, whenever you run git pull
I've been rebasing on purpose; I thought it was reasonable. I feel I've failed as a software person.
Another useful command is git reset --hard HEAD~n where n is an integer that tells you how many commits you want to skip back
I am sadly all to familiar with that one

Cody Roux said:

I've been rebasing on purpose; I thought it was reasonable. I feel I've failed as a software person.

I am not too fluent with rebasing myself. It is a finnicky command
In _theory_ it can help keep the tree from looking too crazy, though I'm not sure that's such a bad thing https://www.atlassian.com/git/tutorials/merging-vs-rebasing
but if any spec of dust gets in there, you're toast
It's a surgeon's scalpel
I think you might find it easier with the git graph extension
I have done my fair share of clean rebases and merges and also diff views with it
https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=mhutchie.git-graph

Ok so: I have yet another branch that builds on Completeness + compactness, but I haven't touched the .tex stuff: what should I do?

  1. Mark my second PR as cancelled, PR the new branch with fingers crossed for the 3rd one
  2. Try to fix the second PR then make a new one
  3. wait to have the tex stuff all fixed up and make one big PR later
Might I suggest just pushing ahead with the PR
The blueprint can be updated in another task
Normally I wouldn't recommend separating docs from code, but since you are adding a large amount of stuff, it might make sense to split it into byte sized portions anyway

Ok cool; for my sanity, can we figure out whether https://github.com/teorth/equational_theories/pull/123 builds or not? I'm gonna have to merge anyway, but I'd like to know why it's green in the checks.
Also, the procedure to link a new PR is to first comment withdraw PR #old_PR_number and then in a new comment, propose PR #xyz

Screenshot_20240930-233324.png
It seems to have succeeded
So do I need to touch it at all at the moment?
(god software is fragile)
From my side, I think it's done. But since @Pietro Monticone reviewed it, I should defer to him

Cody Roux said:

(god software is fragile)

True, but I like to think that software is just mathematics(at least logic) at scale. It trains us in precision thinking.
@Pietro Monticone : I suggest that if the code is fine, we merge this PR and create new tasks that Cody can claim for the blueprint stuff.

The code isn't fine (see my previous comment).

The point is that Completeness.lean doesn't compile.
Then how does it pass CI?

Shreyas Srinivas said:

Screenshot_20240930-233324.png
It seems to have succeeded

This specifically
As I said above in point 2., the reason why the checks pass is simply that Completeness.lean is not imported in the build file equational_theories.lean.
Right. This needs fixing
The issue arises in the proof of the theorem substLFId.
I see it, and fixed it. Is there a command I need to run to check that everything is kosher?

so you need to add the import to the top level equational_theories.lean file

Pietro Monticone said:

As I said above in point 2., the reason why the checks pass is simply that Completeness.lean is not imported in the build file equational_theories.lean.
Don't worry. I will push it in a moment.
I can also add the relevant \lean{} macros if you want @Cody Roux
I'd love it, though I promise to do better next time and actually get it working myself
And all yinz kind help is greatly appreciated
I will also add \leanok to those definition declarations because they're all formalised.
Done.
Thank you very much @Cody Roux. You have done a lot of work!

There is still a lot to do in those LaTeX files:

  • missing proof environments (without with we can display the relevant theorems as properly formally proven)
  • missing \uses{}
  • etc.

But I think it's perfectly fine for now.

I'll probably clean those Lean and the LaTeX files tomorrow.
Now everything works here equational#123
Merged.
I've added a quick section of the blueprint on the compactness theorem, that you are welcome to build upon (and to link the theorems in the blueprint to the Lean theorems).
Cody Roux has marked this topic as resolved.
